Congressman Stevens who was Chairman of the Committee in the House said, "We have looked at these constitutions, we have pronounced them Republican in form and all we propose to require is that they shall remain so forever, subject to this requirement, we are willing to admit them into the Union.
All we propose to require is that they remain Republican in form.”
Now, I think that is very significant language and it comes from the Chairman of the Committee as showing what Congress was thinking about.
This goes back to -- prior to the Act of 1867.
The States -- the ten States remaining, Tennessee came in early but the others had submitted constitutions which were somewhat modified by -- in one way or another.
They hoped that that would meet with the approval of Congress.

And those constitutions were submitted to Congress and they were rejected, the joint committee on reconstruction presented their report which said, "These constitutions are unacceptable for three reasons.
They were not properly adopted, they are not Republican -- the governments are not Republican in form, and the governments are not loyal to the Union.”
And they --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This contradicts what Thaddeus Stevens said then, even said then, didn't it, certainly.

If you say all they were concerned with was whether it's a Republican form of government and they were rejected or some of them were rejected because they weren't properly adopted, the case asserts more things than a Republic form of government.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: That was with reference to these prior constitutions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I understand that but evidently, Congress was also thinking about those.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: Yes, I think that is true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, then Thaddeus Stevens doesn't confine or define the limits of what was implied in their re-representation of it.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: I think the question of due adoption is a matter of definition of the Constitution.
It isn't the constitution if it isn't duly adopted.
It -- the -- the others were documents that were brought to Congress that a group of people had drafted.
And to call them constitutions that they were constitutions in form.
I don't think that they could be properly be called constitutions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that would be that the reconstruction controversy was whether these bodies were really legal bodies or not.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And we can't sit here and say, well, it wasn't a constitution at all therefore, you rejected it.
Evidently, I don't know how and what you tell me but they gave three grounds, one of which was procedural inadequacy of adoption.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: Yes.
And as the result then, an Act of the Act of March 2, 1867 which laid down the procedures to be followed.
How the conventions were to be elected, how they were to be held, how the constitutions were to be ratified.
Now, all that was implicit in the statement pursuant to the Act of 1867.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, and -- and there was -- there was non-compliance as you say with the majority votes and Congress had specifically wager, didn't it?

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: Yes, it did.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And even that isn't a question of Republican form of government, of course to our great (Inaudible) I think it was part of the voting sometimes around in this country less than the majority of those entitled to vote.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: That -- when not to the question of whether the form of the government adopted by the constitution was Republican but whether the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but that is -- my point is that apparently, that wasn't the only thing Congress was concerned with.

We call -- it specifically said, “We adopt this, we recognize the States or a written representation,” although they not -- did not comply with the specific requirements and instead of shutting their eyes, they specifically dealt with it.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: Well, I think that is true that Representative Stevens was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Overstating it.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: -- overstating it to that extent.
They were concerned with whether they were duly adopted, I think that was a necessary concern.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, why anymore necessary than claiming the boundaries that they didn't have, why is that anymore?
It seems to me for a State who claim what is probably beyond legal authority, according to your view, is no more or no less important than to have a constitution adopted by a meager vote.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: That wasn't the problem that was bothering Congress at this time.
This was not an admission of new States.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: These were existing States and as was pointed out in the debates, it was said, Congressman Bingham said, “Every gentleman knows that you must, under this bill, recognize the boundaries of these States as originally fixed by the sovereignty of this Union and if they stand as they were to this day.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but I also been taking judicial notice that the most frequent controversy in the American civil life among the States is the boundary controversy.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: That is quite true but I think Congress felt that this was no time to be getting into any questions other than the very crucial questions of reconstruction.
The Union here was in a -- an extremely difficult situation.
Here were ten States without adequate government of their own, without representation in Congress, it was a thoroughly unsatisfactory --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is true of the earlier constitutions, isn't it?
But what was (Inaudible) and the constitutions that were rejected earlier.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, it was.
Indeed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Its unsatisfactory condition was a rather new one.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Again with (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: It did.
But Congress was anxious to terminate it as rapidly as possible and --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Terminate what?

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: Terminate the situation to get the Southern States back to representation in Congress.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Some were and some were not.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: I think the debates reflect that Congress as a whole was --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understood that the majority to pass this bill accept the views that the States were not States anymore, they were out.
They've been blotted out and they can only become States by being admitted to the Union on terms which Congress fixed.
President Johnson vetoed, refusing to go on that ground I understood you.
They did reply that there'd be, write new constitution as in order to be a State in Steven's group and that they'd be approved by the Congress.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: They were --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That was my understanding of the history about that.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: I certainly debate --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where --

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: -- to your knowledge of that subject.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- whether that might be -- it maybe that I have read the wrong history but that's what I understood [Laughter] -- what I understood to be the history of the -- of the reconstruction Congress and the purposes of those who required the States.
It had been the States to submit themselves to Congress before they -- it was agreed by the Congress that they would.

turn.speaker: george_s_swarth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Swarth
turn.text: It certainly is true, they were required to submit new constitutions before their Senators --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: For a submission, examination and approvals.
